transcribedText: What I want to do today, since this is Build as a Startup School, is share with you some lessons I've learned about building startups at AI Fund. AI Fund is a venture studio, and we build an average of about one startup per month. And because we co-found the startups, we're in there writing code, talking to customers, designing our features, determining pricing. And so we've done a lot of reps of not just watching others build startups, but actually being in the weeds, building startups with entrepreneurs. And what I want to do today is share with you some of the lessons I've learned building startups, especially around this changing AI technology and what it enables. And we focus on the theme of speed. So it turns out that for those of you that want to build a startup, I think a strong predictor for startups' odds of success is execution speed. And I have a lot of respect for the entrepreneurs and executives that can just do things really quickly. And new AI technology is enabling startups to go much faster. So what I hope to do is share with you some of those best practices, which are frankly changing every two to three months still, to let you get that speed that hopefully lets you have a higher odds of success. Before diving into speed, a lot of people ask me, hey, Andrew, where are the opportunities for startups? So this is what I think of as an AI stack, where at the lowest level are the semiconductor companies, then the clouds are hyperscalers built on top of that, a lot of the AI foundation model companies built on top of that, and even though a lot of PR excitement and hype has been on these technology layers, it turns out that almost by definition, the biggest opportunities have to be at the application layer, because we actually need the applications to generate even more revenue so that they can afford to pay the foundation, cloud and semiconductor technology layers. So for whatever reason, media and social media tends not to talk about the application layer as much. But for those of you thinking of building startups, almost by definition, the biggest opportunities have to be there, although of course, the opportunities are all layers of the stack. One of the things that's changed a lot over the last year, and in terms of AI tech trends, if you ask me what's the most important tech trend in AI, I would say it's the rise of agentic AI. And about a year and a half ago, when I started to go around and give talks to try to convince people that AI agents might be a thing, I did not realize that around last summer, a bunch of marketers would get a hold of this term and use it as a sticker and slap it on everything in sight, which made it almost lose some of its meaning. But I want to share with you from a technical perspective, why I think agentic AI is exciting and important and also opens up a lot more startup opportunities. So it turns out that the way a lot of us use OMs is to prompt it, to have it generate output. And the way we have an OOM output something is as if you're going to a human or in this case an AI and asking it to please type out an essay for you by writing from the first word.

slides.title: Introduction to Building Startups
slides.content: Today, I'll share lessons learned from building startups at AI Fund, a venture studio creating about one startup a month.
slides.speakerNotes: Introduce the topic of building startups with firsthand experience from AI Fund. Emphasize the hands-on approach in co-founding startups and the practical insights gained.

slides.title: Focus on Speed
slides.content: Execution speed is a strong predictor of startup success. AI technology is enabling faster execution, crucial for startup success. Best practices are changing rapidly.
slides.speakerNotes: Highlight the importance of speed in startup execution. Explain how AI advances contribute to faster operations, enhancing success odds. Mention the evolving best practices.

slides.title: Opportunities in the AI Stack
slides.content: AI stack consists of semiconductor companies at the base, followed by clouds, AI foundation models, and finally, the application layer with the biggest opportunities.
slides.speakerNotes: Illustrate the AI stack layers and stress on the application layer having significant opportunities, despite media focus on technology layers. Encourage exploration across all layers.

slides.title: Rise of Agentic AI
slides.content: Agentic AI, marked as a major tech trend, drives startup opportunities. Despite its diluted popularity, it holds technical importance and potential.
slides.speakerNotes: Explain the concept of agentic AI and why it matters. Address the hype dilution and emphasize its genuine technical potentials for startups.

slides.title: Implications of Agentic AI
slides.content: Using agentic AI involves prompting OM technology to perform tasks as if instructing a human, opening new interaction paradigms.
slides.speakerNotes: Describe how agentic AI operates, using OMs for outputs akin to human instructions. Highlight the novel possibilities it introduces for startups.

slides.title: Conclusion and Takeaways
slides.content: Leverage speed with AI innovations, explore the application layer for opportunities, and embrace new tech trends like agentic AI for startup success.
slides.speakerNotes: Summarize the key points: focus on speed, application layer opportunities, and innovative trends like agentic AI. Encourage actionable steps based on insights shared.
